analyzed: anyathā upādhi saṃgrahasya api asaṃbhavāt iti ced
translated: If it is said that this is because even the inclusion of an attribute would be impossible if it were otherwise,🔽then what?

original: tavāpi vā tatra sāmānyamupalakṣaṇena saṃgṛhyate / na vā /
analyzed: tava api vā tatra sāmānyam upalakṣaṇena saṃgṛhyate na vā
translated: Or is the universal also included there by indication? No.

analyzed: pūrvatra anyathā asiddhiḥ anavasthitiḥ ca
translated: In the former case, there is establishment in another way and infinite regress.

analyzed: uttaratra niyāmaka adarśanāt jāteḥ āśraya vyavasthā na syāt
translated: In the latter case, there would be no establishment of the substratum of the universal, because no determining factor is seen.

original: vyāvṛttānāmapi svabhāvata eva kāsāṃcit vyaktīnāṃ tadvyañjakatvaniyatiriti cet /
analyzed: vyāvṛttānām api svabhāvataḥ eva kāsāṃcid vyaktīnām tad vyañjaka tva niyatiḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that some individuals, even though different, are restricted to manifest that by their very nature,

original: sa eva svabhāvaḥ kiṃ na vyavahāraṃ niyachet /
analyzed: saḥ eva svabhāvaḥ kim na vyavahāram niyacchet
translated: why should that very nature not determine usage?

analyzed: nirviṣayaḥ katham vyavahāraḥ syāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that how can usage be objectless,

original: tāsāmeva vyaktīnāṃ viṣayatvāt /🔽vyāvṛttānāmanuvṛttavyavahāraviṣayatve sarvatra viṣayavyavasthā bhajyeteti cet /
analyzed: tāsām eva vyaktīnām viṣaya tvāt  vyāvṛttānām anuvṛtta vyavahāra viṣaya tve sarvatra viṣaya vyavasthā bhajyeta iti ced
translated: because those very individuals are the objects,🔽if it is argued that in the case of different things being the object of a continuing usage, the restriction of the object would be violated everywhere,

original: vyāvṛttānāmanuvṛttavyañjakatve sarvatra tadvyaktiḥ kiṃ na syāt / /
analyzed: vyāvṛttānām anuvṛtta vyañjaka tve sarvatra tad vyaktiḥ kim na syāt
translated: why should the manifestation of those different things not be everywhere in the case of different things being the manifesters of a continuing usage?

original: saṃbandhāsaṃbandhābhyāṃ niyamāditi cenna /🔽saṃbandhasyāpi samavāyanāmnaḥ sārvatrikatvābhyupagamāt tatrāpyabhivyaktipratiniyamasya mṛgyatvāt /
analyzed: saṃbandha asaṃbandhābhyām niyamāt iti ced na  saṃbandhasya api samavāya nāmnaḥ sārvatrika tva abhyupagamāt tatra api abhivyakti pratiniyamasya mṛgya tvāt
translated: If it is argued that it is because of the restriction due to connection and non-connection, it is not so.🔽Because even connection, which is called inherence, is accepted as being everywhere, and the restriction of manifestation there is also to be sought.

analyzed: nānā samavāya vādaḥ api vyakti svabhāva niyamasya dustyaja tvāt
translated: Even in the doctrine of multiple inherence, the restriction of the nature of the individual is difficult to abandon.

original: tathāpi dṛṣṭaikagovyaktervyaktyantare soyamiti pratyabhijñānaṃ kathaṃ syāt /
analyzed: tathā api dṛṣṭa eka go vyakteḥ vyakti antare saḥ uyam iti pratyabhijñānam katham syāt
translated: Even so, how can there be recognition in another individual of the cow seen once, thinking this is the same?

original: ayaṃ gaurityekavyaktau vyutpāditaśca kathaṃ vyaktyatyantarepi tacchabdavācyatāṃ pratīyāt /
analyzed: ayam gauḥ iti eka vyaktau vyutpāditaḥ ca katham vyakti atyantare pi tad śabda vācya tām pratīyāt
translated: And how can one, taught that this is a cow with reference to one individual, understand that the same word applies to another individual?

analyzed: iti ced tava api vā katham
translated: If this is argued, how is it for you?

analyzed: eka dharma samavāyāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that it is due to the inherence of one property,

original: tenaiva dharmeṇa svato militasya samavāyasyaiva nityaṃ sarvatra vṛttyabhyupagamena sarvatra sarvavyavahārasaṃkaraprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: tena eva dharmeṇa svatas militasya samavāyasya eva nityam sarvatra vṛtti abhyupagamena sarvatra sarva vyavahāra saṃkara prasaṅgāt
translated: then, due to the acceptance of the inherence of that very property, which is united with itself, as always operating everywhere, there would be the undesirable consequence of the confusion of all practical usage everywhere.

analyzed: kāsāṃcid eva vyaktīnām tad vyañjaka tva svābhāvyāt vyavasthā uktā iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the restriction is due to the natural capacity of some individuals to manifest that [property],

analyzed: tarhi tāsām eva vyaktīnām pratisaṃdhāna vyavahārayoḥ viṣaya tvam astu
translated: then let the objects of the recollection and practical usage be just those individuals.

original: tathā sati bhrāntatvaṃ tayoḥ syāditi cenna /
analyzed: tathā sati bhrānta tvam tayoḥ syāt iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that in that case those two would be erroneous, it is not so.

analyzed: tad vyakti tvena pratisaṃdhāna ādeḥ abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no recollection etc. in terms of those individuals.

original: api tarhi tathātvena vyaktisvarūpātiriktaṃ tathātvaṃ nāmāntareṇa jātireva syāditi cet /
analyzed: api tarhi tathātvena vyakti svarūpa atiriktam tathātvam nāma antareṇa jātiḥ eva syāt iti ced
translated: If it is argued that in that case, the universal itself, which is different from the nature of the individuals, would be the same thing under another name,🔽it is not so.

original: tajjātivyañjakaṃ tattadekavyaktisvarūpātiriktaṃ kiṃ na jātyantaraṃ syāt / /
analyzed: tad jāti vyañjakam tad tad eka vyakti svarūpa atiriktam kim na jāti antaram syāt
translated: Why should not that which manifests that class be another class apart from the form of that individual?

original: upādhiviśeṣa evāyaṃ pratiniyatāśraya iti cet /🔽evaṃ tarhi pratiniyatapratiyogikaṃ svabhāvaniyataṃ parasparasmārakatvamupajīvya tajjātīyatayā pratisaṃdhānavyavahāropapattau kimanyakalpanena🔽tasmārakataditaravibhāgaḥ kutastya iti cet /
analyzed: upādhi viśeṣaḥ eva ayam pratiniyata āśrayaḥ iti ced  evam tarhi pratiniyata pratiyogikam svabhāva niyatam paraspara smāraka tvam upajīvya tad jātīya tayā pratisaṃdhāna vyavahāra upapattau kim anya kalpanena  tasmāraka tad itara vibhāgaḥ kutastyaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that this is only a particular attribute with a restricted substratum,🔽then, in that case, when the cognition of connection is possible by the mutual recollection based on the restricted counter-correlate and the natural restriction, what is the use of assuming anything else?🔽If it is asked how the distinction between the remembrancer and the non-remembrancer arises,

analyzed: tad vyañjaka tad itara vibhāgaḥ te kutastyaḥ
translated: how does the distinction between the manifester and the non-manifester arise for you?

analyzed: darśana adarśana āyattaḥ iti ced tulyam
translated: If it is said to be dependent on seeing and not seeing, it is the same.

analyzed: saṃbandha sādṛśyayoḥ abhāve katham smāraka tvam iti ced
translated: If it is asked how there can be the nature of a remembrancer in the absence of relation and similarity,

analyzed: tayoḥ vā katham
translated: how can there be those two?

analyzed: sadṛśa saha anubhūta darśanasya saṃskāra udbodhaka tvāt iti ced
translated: If it is said that the seeing of the similar and the previously experienced is the awakener of the impression,

analyzed: tat api kutas
translated: how is that possible?

analyzed: kārya darśanāt kalpyate iti ced
translated: If it is said that it is inferred from the perception of the effect,

original: tulyam / anyathā saṃbandhaṃ sādṛśyaṃ vaikamupādāya tadanyasya kathaṃ smārakatvamiti codyasya durvāratvāt /
analyzed: tulyam anyathā saṃbandham sādṛśyam vā ekam upādāya tad anyasya katham smāraka tvam iti codyasya durvāra tvāt
translated: it is the same. Otherwise, the objection that how can the other be a remembrancer on the basis of a relation or similarity that is different cannot be avoided.

analyzed: na ca atra sādṛśyam na aṅgīkurmaḥ
translated: And we do not deny similarity in this case.

analyzed: sausādṛśya rūpa tva abhyupagamāt sāmānyasya
translated: Because the universal is accepted to be of the nature of similarity.

analyzed: nāma antareṇa para abhimata jāti svīkāraḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the acceptance of a different class is desired by others,

analyzed: vyāvṛttānām saṃniveśa ādīnām eva pratiniyata pratiyogi smāraka svabhāva tayā sādṛśya rūpa tvāt
translated: because only the differentiated arrangements etc. have the nature of being the cause of the recollection of the particular counter-correlate, and are of the nature of similarity.

analyzed: gavaya ādeḥ api tarhi go jātīya tva ādi prasaṅgaḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that then the gavaya etc. would also be of the class of cows, it is not so.

analyzed: sādṛśya sausādṛśya vibhāga svaya sāṃpratyayikasya sarva saṃmata tvāt iti
translated: Because the division of similarity and dissimilarity is well-known to all, as it is self-evident.

original: evaṃ sāmānyādiṣu sūtrakārādibhirnirasteṣu pariśiṣṭā dravyaguṇakarmarūpāstrayaḥ padārthāḥ iti kecidācāryāḥ //
analyzed: evam sāmānya ādiṣu sūtrakāra ādibhiḥ nirasteṣu pariśiṣṭāḥ dravya guṇa karma rūpāḥ trayaḥ padārthāḥ iti kecid ācāryāḥ
translated: Thus, when universals etc. have been refuted by the author of the aphorisms etc., some teachers say that the remaining three categories are substance, quality and action.

original: nyā / pa / prame / anye tu manyanteyathā tatpratīteranyathāsiddhatayā te padārthā bhāṣyakārādibhirnirasyante /
analyzed: anye tu manyante yathā tad pratīteḥ anyathā asiddha tayā te padārthāḥ bhāṣyakāra ādibhiḥ nirasyante
translated: Others, however, think that just as those categories are refuted by the author of the commentary etc. on the ground that their cognition is otherwise established,

analyzed: tathā karma api iti
translated: so also is action.

original: ye tāvadiha sarvatra sūryaparispandādivadapratyakṣaṃ karma phalānumeyamicchanti /
analyzed: ye tāvat iha sarvatra sūrya parispanda ādi vat apratyakṣam karma phala anumeyam icchanti
translated: Those who here everywhere desire action, which is imperceptible like the motion of the sun etc., to be inferred from the fruit,

original: tatra yayā sāmagryā karmaṇaḥ siddhirabhimatā tayaiva dṛṣṭaṃ karmaphalaṃ sādhyatām /
analyzed: tatra yayā sāmagryā karmaṇaḥ siddhiḥ abhimatā tayā eva dṛṣṭam karma phalam sādhyatām
translated: in that case, let the seen fruit of action be accomplished by the very same set of conditions by which the establishment of action is desired.

analyzed: kim antarā kalpitena karmaṇā
translated: What is the use of assuming an intervening action?

analyzed: tathā api ced kḷptiḥ
translated: Even if it were so, there would be an infinite regress.

analyzed: anyatra api kāla viprakarṣa adarśane pi sāmagrī kāryayoḥ madhye anyasya kḷpti prasaṅgaḥ
translated: Even in other cases, even when there is no perception of remoteness in time, there would be the undesirable consequence of assuming another action between the cause and effect of the assemblage.

analyzed: tathā eva ca tra tra api iti anavasthā syāt
translated: And in the same way, there would be an infinite regress here also.

analyzed: ye ca pratyakṣam karma iti āhuḥ
translated: And those who say that action is directly perceived,

original: tairapi nūnaṃ karmaphalatvenābhyupagamasaṃyogavibhāgātiriktaṃ nipuṇanirīkṣaṇepi nopalabhyata iti manyāmahe /
analyzed: taiḥ api nūnam karma phala tvena abhyupagama saṃyoga vibhāga atiriktam nipuṇa nirīkṣaṇe api nā upalabhyate iti manyāmahe
translated: we think that even by careful examination, they do not perceive anything other than conjunction and disjunction accepted as the effect of action.

analyzed: calati pratyayaḥ api hi tāvatā eva caritārthaḥ
translated: Even the notion of motion is fulfilled by just that much.

original: na ca vācyaṃ yāvatsaṃyogaṃ calatipratyayaprasaṅga iti /
analyzed: na ca vācyam yāvat saṃyogam calati pratyaya prasaṅgaḥ iti
translated: And it should not be said that there would be the undesirable consequence of the notion of motion lasting as long as the conjunction.

analyzed: pūrva deśa vibhāga pūrvaka deśa antara saṃyoga prathama kṣaṇa viṣaya tvāt tad pratyayasya
translated: Because the notion has as its object the first moment of disjunction from the previous place and conjunction with another place.

original: tata eva hyuttarakāle saṃyoge vartamānepyacaladiti bhūtānusaṃdhānamupapannam /
analyzed: tatas eva hi uttara kāle saṃyoge vartamāne ipi acalat iti bhūta anusaṃdhānam upapannam
translated: And it is precisely from that that the remembrance of the past as 'not moving' is possible at a later time, even when the conjunction is present.

original: nanu pravāhamadhyasthite sthāṇau pūrvasalilaskandhaviyogaḥ uttarasalilaskandhayogaśca dṛśyate /
analyzed: nanu pravāha madhya sthite sthāṇau pūrva salila skandha viyogaḥ uttara salila skandha yogaḥ ca dṛśyate
translated: But in the case of a post situated in the middle of a stream, disjunction from the previous mass of water and conjunction with the subsequent mass of water are seen.

analyzed: na ca tatra calatvam icchāmaḥ
translated: And we do not wish to attribute motion to it.

original: vyomādaya eva sthiradeśatvena vivakṣitāḥ iti cenna /
analyzed: vyoma ādayaḥ eva sthira deśa tvena vivakṣitāḥ iti ced na
translated: If it is argued that only space etc. are intended to be the fixed locations, that is not so.

analyzed: pravāhasya tatas viśeṣa adarśanāt
translated: Because no difference is seen in the continuum from that.

analyzed: laulyam viśeṣaḥ iti ced
translated: If it is argued that the difference is in the form of restlessness,

original: tarhi saṃyogavibhāgātiriktaṃ laulyarūpaṃ karmapratyakṣamiti kathaṃ tadapahnavaḥ / iti /
analyzed: tarhi saṃyoga vibhāga atiriktam laulya rūpam karma pratyakṣam iti katham tad apahnavaḥ iti
translated: then how can the denial be made that action in the form of restlessness, which is perceptible apart from conjunction and disjunction, is perceptible?

original: tatrāhuḥyā nāma karmasāmagrī tvayeṣyate sā tattatkarmaphalatayābhimataṃ saṃyogaviśeṣamutpādayantī niyatasvabhāvameva tamutpādayati /
analyzed: tatra āhuḥ yā nāma karma sāmagrī tvayā iṣyate sā tad tad karma phalatayā abhimatam saṃyoga viśeṣam utpādayantī niyata svabhāvam eva tam utpādayati
translated: Regarding that, they say: The collection of actions that you accept produces the particular conjunction that is accepted as the fruit of each action, and it produces that which is of a fixed nature itself.

original: ata eva eva saṃyogonekaniṣṭhopi san kvaciccalatipratyaṃyaṃ kvacit saṃyogamātrapratyayaṃ ca janayati /
analyzed: atas eva eva saṃyoga ūneka niṣṭhaḥ api san kvacid calati pratyaṃyam kvacid saṃyoga mātra pratyayam ca janayati
translated: For this very reason, even though the conjunction is based on many, it produces the cognition of motion in some cases and the cognition of mere conjunction in some cases.

original: yathaika eva samavāyoguṇaguṇibhyāmaviśeṣeṇa svato militopi san kvacidāśrayapratyayaṃ kvacidāśritapratyayaṃ ca janayati /
analyzed: yathā ekaḥ eva samavāyaḥ guṇa guṇibhyām aviśeṣeṇa svatas militaḥ api san kvacid āśraya pratyayam kvacid āśrita pratyayam ca janayati
translated: Just as the very same inherence, though united with the quality and the possessor of the quality without distinction, produces the cognition of the substratum in some cases and the cognition of the subordinate in some cases.

analyzed: na hi āśraya bhāvaḥ āśrita bhāvaḥ vā samavāya svarūpa atiriktaḥ
translated: For the state of being a substratum or the state of being a subordinate is not different from the nature of inherence.

analyzed: tadvat iha api iti
translated: It is the same here also.

analyzed: vayam tu brūmaḥ apratyakṣa karma vādaḥ tāvat prāc ukta dūṣaṇāt ayuktaḥ
translated: But we say that the doctrine of imperceptible action is not proper due to the previously stated faults.

analyzed: pratyakṣam tu karma svarūpataḥ durapahnavam
translated: But action is directly perceptible, and its nature is difficult to deny.

analyzed: tatra bhāṣya ādiṣu atireka vidhi niṣedha adarśanāt artha antara virodha abhāvāt ca udāsitavyam iti
translated: There, in the commentaries etc., it should be stated because of the non-observation of injunctions and prohibitions regarding excess, and because there is no contradiction with other meanings.

original: idaṃ tu manyāmahe atirekepi guṇavargānna rāśyantaraṃ karma /
analyzed: idam tu manyāmahe atireke api guṇa vargāt na rāśi antaram karma
translated: But we think that even in excess, action is not a separate class from the group of qualities.

analyzed: vibhājaka abhāvāt
translated: Because there is no dividing factor.

original: svecchākalpitavibhājakasya sarvatra sulabhatvena yathābhimatamekaṃ guṇamubhayaṃ vāṅgīkṛtya rāśyantarakalpanaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: sva icchā kalpita vibhājakasya sarvatra sulabha tvena yathā abhimatam ekam guṇam ubhayam vā aṅgīkṛtya rāśi antara kalpana prasaṅgāt
translated: Because it is easy to find everywhere a dividing factor imagined by one's own will, and because there is the possibility of postulating a separate class by accepting either one or both qualities as desired.
Because there is no contradiction with the quality of the diversity of the internal qualities.

analyzed: atas dravyam adravyam iti eva vibhāgaḥ iti
translated: Therefore, the division is only between substance and non-substance.

original: nyā / pa / prame / tatra cātmaguṇatayābhimateṣu sukhaduḥkhecchādveṣaprayatnāḥ pañca tattadutpādakatayābhimatabuddhiviśeṣānatiriktā vedārthasaṃgrahe 🔽samarthitāḥ /
analyzed: nyā pa prame  tatra ca ātma guṇa tayā abhimateṣu sukha duḥkha icchā dveṣa prayatnāḥ pañca tad tad utpādaka tayā abhimata buddhi viśeṣa anatiriktāḥ vedārthasaṃgrahe 🔽samarthitāḥ
translated: Nyā. Pa. Pram. There, among the qualities of the self that are accepted, pleasure, pain, desire, aversion, and effort are five, and they are not different from the particular cognitions accepted as producing them, as is demonstrated in the Vedārthasangraha.

analyzed: dharma adharmau vihita niṣiddha kriyā sādhya tayā abhimatau ājñāvataḥ rājñaḥ iva sarva praśāsituḥ īśvarasya anugraha nigraha ākhya buddhi viśeṣa rūpau bhāṣya ādiṣu
translated: Dharma and Adharma are accepted as accomplished by enjoined and prohibited actions, like the king who is obeyed, as the special form of the mind called grace and restraint of the Lord who rules over all, as stated in the commentaries etc.

analyzed: bahuṣu pradeśeṣu prapañcitau
translated: Dharma and adharma are accepted as accomplished by enjoined and prohibited actions, like the king's favor and punishment, which are the forms of special intelligence called favor and punishment for the Lord, the ruler of all, as explained in many sections of the Bhāṣya and other texts.

analyzed: yaḥ punar saṃskāraḥ sa tāvat buddhi viśeṣa ātmanā uktaḥ
translated: Moreover, that impression is said to be of the nature of a special intelligence.

analyzed: na ca tad prayuktaḥ
translated: And it is not employed by that.

analyzed: tatas cira naṣṭa viprakṛṣṭa ākāre vyāpti adarśanāt
translated: And because the pervasion is not seen in what has long since disappeared or is distant,

original: vāsanānuvṛtteśca vācanikatvāt //🔽nyā / pa / prame / yadyapi indriyasyendriyasyārthe ityādigītāślokeṣu bhāṣyakārairvāsanāyā icchādvāreṇaiva pravṛttihetutvavacanājjñānavāsanāviśeṣātiriktā
analyzed: vāsanā anuvṛtteḥ ca vācanika tvāt  nyā pa prame  yadi api indriyasya indriyasya arthe ityādi gītā ślokeṣu bhāṣyakāraiḥ vāsanāyāḥ icchā dvāreṇa eva pravṛtti hetutva vacanāt jñāna vāsanā viśeṣa atiriktā  /
translated: and because the continuation of impressions is verbal.🔽Although in the Gītā verses beginning with of each sense towards its object, the commentators have stated that impressions are the cause of activity only through desire, so there is no karma-vāsanā

analyzed: karma vāsanā na asti
translated: apart from the special knowledge-vāsanā.

analyzed: tathā api jñāna vāsanā durapahnavā
translated: Nevertheless, the knowledge-vāsanā is undeniable.

analyzed: tatas ca tad āśraya mātram vicāryam
translated: And therefore, only its substratum is to be considered.

analyzed: tatra dharma bhūta jñānasya tad niṣṭha smṛti ākhya vikāra utpādakaḥ saṃskāraḥ api tad niṣṭhaḥ
translated: There, for those who follow the established view of the Bhāṣya and other texts that knowledge, which is a quality, has substance as its substratum, the impression that produces the modification called memory, which has that [substance] as its substratum, is also that [substance].

analyzed: antaraṅga tvāt abādhāt ca
translated: Because of being more internal and because of non-obstruction.

original: nyā / pa / prame / ye tu paraparibhāṣamanusarantastadanuguṇaṃ tasya guṇatvaṃ gṛhṇanti /
analyzed: ye tu para paribhāṣam anusarantaḥ tad anuguṇam tasya guṇa tvam gṛhṇanti
translated: Those who follow the definitions of others accept its quality in accordance with that.

analyzed: teṣām ātmani eva saṃskāraḥ
translated: For them, there is only purification of the self.

analyzed: iti viśeṣaḥ
translated: This is the difference.

original: na ca buddhornityatvaṃ saṃkocavikāsādidaśābhedaṃ cābhyupagacchadbhiradravyatvaṃ tasyāḥ suvacam /
analyzed: na ca buddhoḥ nitya tvam saṃkoca vikāsa ādi daśā bhedam ca abhyupagacchadbhiḥ adravya tvam tasyāḥ suvacam
translated: And for those who accept the eternality of the intellect and the difference in states such as contraction and expansion, it is not well-said that it is not a substance.

analyzed: avasthā antara yogi tvam eva hi upādana tvam
translated: For being connected with a different state is itself the quality of being a material cause.

analyzed: tat eva hi dravya lakṣaṇam
translated: That is indeed the definition of a substance.

analyzed: tathā api na guṇa tva hāniḥ
translated: Even so, there is no loss of being a quality.

analyzed: śuddha sattva ākhyasya ca dravya antarasya para vigraha ādi yāthārthya upadeśa pravṛtta nirukta ādi āpta āgama siddha tvāt sūkṣma triguṇa avasthā viśeṣa ādi pakṣāḥ bahiṣkāryāḥ
translated: And because the existence of another substance called pure sattva is established by the authoritative scriptures such as Nirukta, which teach the true meaning of the body of the supreme self and so on, the views of it being a subtle state of the three gunas and so on should be rejected.

analyzed: atas ṣaḍ etāni dravyāṇi
translated: Therefore, these are the six substances.

original: bhoktṛbhogyaniyantṝṇāṃ sadātmanaikadravyatvādipakṣā api nirviśeṣasanmātrapakṣavad vyāghātaśrutivirodhādibhirbahuśo bhāṣyādiṣu nirastāḥ /
analyzed: bhoktṛ bhogya niyantṝṇām sat ātmanā eka dravya tva ādi pakṣāḥ api nirviśeṣa sanmātra pakṣa vat vyāghāta śruti virodha ādibhiḥ bahuśas bhāṣya ādiṣu nirastāḥ
translated: The views that the enjoyer, the object of enjoyment, and the controller are of the nature of the eternal self, and are of the nature of a single substance, etc., like the view of pure Being without distinctions, have been refuted many times in the commentaries etc. due to contradictions, conflicts with the scriptures, etc.

analyzed: tatra triguṇa śuddha sattve sva niruktyā eva lakṣye
translated: There, in pure sattva with three qualities, the definition itself defines the object.

analyzed: kṣaṇa lava ādi ātmā kālaḥ
translated: Time has the nature of kṣaṇa, lava, etc.

analyzed: aṇuḥ jñātā jīvaḥ
translated: The atom is the known jīva.

analyzed: vibhuḥ tu īśvaraḥ
translated: The all-pervading one is Īśvara.
The special cause of the usage of knows is the cognition, which is the special object of usage.

analyzed: evam triguṇa kāla jīva īśvara śuddha sattva mati rūpeṇa ṣoḍhā dravya vibhāgaḥ
translated: Thus, the division of substances is sixfold in the form of pure sattva with three qualities, time, jīva, Īśvara, and cognition.

analyzed: evam pramāṇa sārtha ghaṇṭāpathena dravya adravya rūpa prameya grāmam adhijigamiṣatām na kudṛṣṭi bāhya kalpita kūṭa yukti garta nipātaḥ iti
translated: Thus, for those who wish to reach the group of objects to be known in the form of substances and non-substances by the path of the bell of the assembly of means of knowledge, there is no falling into the pit of false reasoning imagined by outsiders.

original: iti śrīkavitārkikasiṃhasya sarvatantrasvatantrasya śrīmadveṅkaṭanāthasya vedāntācāryasya kṛtiṣu nyāyapariśuddhau prameyādhyāye prathamamāhnikam
analyzed: iti śrī kavi tārkikasiṃhasya sarva tantra svatantrasya śrīmat veṅkaṭanāthasya vedānta ācāryasya kṛtiṣu nyāyapariśuddhau prameya adhyāye prathamam āhnikam
translated: Thus ends the first chapter in the Nyāyapariśuddhi, a treatise on the categories of knowledge composed by the illustrious Vedāntācārya Veṅkaṭanātha, the independent master of all scriptures and the lion among poets and logicians.
